nodes.bodyText: Instead of doing this, I suggest looking up the pod object and then using the pods nodeName so nodeName can change.

Is it something that may happen today, or the goal is to make the code more flexible.
If instance id in the task context is different from node instance id, it is a major consistency issue.
It is to make it more flexible as the nodeName in the future may not match the instance id.

Adding a new task attribute:
public static final String TASK_ATTRIBUTES_KUBE_NODE_NAME = "kube.nodeName"
I think there should be a better message here. Maybe Agent terminated due to underlying issue?
👍, something like: Terminated due to an issue with the underlying host machine
If there are many Accepted entries in the status history then you might not get the correct one.
minor: add (matcher, reasonString) pairs to a collection and findFirst() on it to reduce duplication here
I would prefer to keep it as it is, in case in the future we need more complex logic when parsing reason messages or checking additional information in the task state.
log something and/or emit a metric so we know when reconciliation is not running? Or alternatively, emit a metric when it runs
suggestion, something like: Abandoned with unknown state due to lack of status updates from the host machine
In the TaskState.Accepted && hasPod() case, I think we need a grace time to allow state propagation through kube-apiserver and our informers, otherwise we may be killing tasks prematurely
